data.text: The Western Highlands are situated in the north and west of our country.
These extend from the Makran Coast in the south to the extreme northern mountainous region.
The Siwaliks or Sub-Himalayas is the southernmost range of the Himalayas.
Beyond the Siwaliks, lies the Lesser Himalayas which are higher than the Siwaliks.
The Great Himalayas form the highest part of the North.
The average height of the Karakoram mountains is 6100 metres.
Mount Godwin Austen (K2), the second highest peak of the world, lies in the Karakoram Range. It is 8611 metres high.
The Karakoram Highway connects Pakistan to China.
The Balochistan Plateau lies to the west of the Sulaiman and Kirthar ranges.
The Potohar Plateau lies between the Jhelum and Indus rivers.
The source of the Indus is near Lake Mansorawar in Tibet.
The plains formed by the River Indus provide Pakistan with its best agricultural land.
The rivers Jhelum, Chenab, Ravi, and Sutlej join together at Panjnad and then join the Indus at Mithankot.
The Karakoram mountains form the extreme northern boundary of Pakistan.
The Hindu Kush mountains form the north and north-western borders of Pakistan.
The Kohistan, Swat, and Dir ranges lie to the south of the Hindu Kush range.
The Indus is the most important river in Pakistan.
